newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Visa's second quarter Asia trade volume up 25 pct.
newsitem.headline: Visa's second quarter Asia trade volume up 25 pct.

text.p: Credit card company Visa International said in a statement on Monday that its second quarter 1996 Asia-Pacific trading volume was up 25 percent year on year to US$27.5 billion.
Full year comparison for the 12 months ended June 30, 1996, saw volumes rise to a record US$104.1 billion, also a increase of 25 per cent, it said.
Visa said it has issued about 94 million cards in the region, which were used in 712.9 million transactions in the 12 months to June 30, 1996.

The biggest growths in volume in the quarter were recorded in India and Pakistan at 80 percent (to US$60 million) and 59 percent (to US$30 million) respectively against the second quarter of 1995, said the statement.
Singapore had the slowest volume growth of 13 percent to US$740 million in the three months to June 30, 1996 compared to the same period in 1995.
Strong growth in volume was also recorded in Taiwan (57 percent), Philippines (55 percent), Malaysia (42 percent) and Australia (35 percent).
The figures include goods and services purchasing in China, which saw volume up 34 percent to US$5.1 billion in the 12 months to June 30.

Japan remains Visa's biggest Asia-Pacific market with 53.5 million cards and 38 percent of the volume (US$39 billion) for the 12 months ending June. South Korea is second biggest with about 21 percent of volume (US$21.5 billion) from 10.8 million cards.
Visa is a worldwide payment card system grouping 20,000 member financial institutions and 13 million locations accepting the card as payment.
